http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Visual Art I-IV are two-semester courses designed to teach students to apply the elements of art and the principles of design. Students are expected to use a variety of media, techniques, processes, and tools to create original artwork that demonstrates understanding of aesthetic concerns and complex compositions. These basic concepts are introduced at the Visual Art I level. As students progress through each course, they will develop, expand, and increase their real life application of problem solving through artistic maturation. Students will create, critique, reflect, and make connections to art. Students will exhibit original artwork and develop portfolios that reflect their personal growth. Visual Art I will satisfy the one-half credit fine arts requirement for graduation. Arkansas Department of Education approval is not required for Visual Art I, Visual Art II, Visual Art III, and Visual Art IV.
Creating
Students will generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.
Produce ideas that create multiple solutions to specific visual art problems and reflect artistic expression
Students will organize and develop artistic ideas and work.

Use the elements of art in artistic compositions
  • color (e.g., color wheel, complementary, analogous, monochromatic, triad, warm, cool, split complementary, hue, value, intensity)
  • form (e.g., geometric, organic)
  • line (e.g., contour, implied, gesture, sketch, outline, structural, calligraphic, weight, value, expressive, directional, media influences)
  • shape (e.g., geometric, organic)
  • space (e.g., positive, negative, foreground, middle ground, background, one-point, two-point, aerial perspective, overlap, placement, size, color, illusion of depth)
  • texture (e.g., implied, actual)
  • value (e.g., neutral, light, dark, high key, low key, value ranges)

Use the principles of design in artistic composition
  • balance (e.g., asymmetrical, radial, symmetrical)
  • contrast (e.g., color, form, line, shape, space, texture, value)
  • emphasis (e.g., dominance, focal point)
  • movement (e.g., depth, flow, overlap, placement, repetition, size, time)
  • pattern (e.g., formal, informal, repetition)
  • proportion (e.g., exaggeration, scale)
  • rhythm e.g., pattern, repetition)
  • unity (e.g., repetition, order)
  • harmony (e.g., similarity, wholeness)
  • variety (e.g., difference, diversity)
Practice safety, proper technique, and conservation in the use of tools, materials, and equipment
Students will refine and complete artistic work.
Create artwork(s) with a specific intent using spatial relationships

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., visual measurements, figure, facial, linear perspective, architectural renderings, direct observational drawings

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Render drawings as preliminary sketches or as finished products

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., contour, blind contour, foreshortening, gesture, journal, negative spaces, upside down, mechanical, additive/subtractive, chiaroscuro

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Create artwork(s) with a specific intent from direct observation using wet and dry media

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., gradation, surface qualities, transparency, opacity, color theory

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Create artwork(s) with a specific intent using a variety of media, techniques, processes, and tools

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., printmaking, image transfer, sculpture, jewelry, scratch art, paper arts, fiber arts, collage, calligraphy, technology, photography

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Define a body of work

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., compositions, artistic maturation, personal visual voice, influences of visual cultures, personal influences, personal environments, personal experiences, underlying visual idea, content, theme, series

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Presenting
Students will analyze, interpret, and select artistic work for presentation.
Identify one's own artwork(s) that reflect personal growth
Students will develop and refine artistic work for presentation.
Participate in the process of exhibiting personal artwork(s)

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., plan, select, promote, install, attend

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.
Describe appropriate venues for the presentation of artistic work, based on the meaning to be conveyed

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., museums, professional galleries, online venues, alternative venues

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Responding
Students will perceive and analyze artistic work.

Describe aspects of works of art
  • perceptual influence
  • understanding of human experiences
Students will interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.
Describe the artist's intent in student artwork(s) and works of art in terms of history, culture, and aesthetics

Describe varied subject matter, signs, symbols, icons, and/or ideas from a variety of perspectives
  • media
  • styles
  • techniques
  • history
  • culture
  • aesthetics
Students will apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.
Discuss criteria used when evaluating student artwork(s) and works of art in terms of history, culture, and aesthetics
Connecting
Students will synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.
Discuss selected personal artwork(s) with reference to media, styles, and techniques
Identify personal connections (e.g., self, gender, family, community, history, culture, environment, visual cultures) to one's own artwork(s)
Students will relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural and historical context to deepen understanding.
Describe various purposes for creating art in the context of self, family, community, social and global perspectives

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., aesthetic, cultural, functional, historical, occupational, social, therapeutic, interdisciplinary

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Describe recurring universal themes, concepts, forms, and functions in works of art and design that span cultures, times, and places
Describe social and global impacts of art

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., self, gender, family, community, history, culture environments, visual cultures

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Describe relationships between art and environments

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g. conservation, recycling, emerging environmental issues
